  • Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) should not be used for the primary prevention of cardiovascular disease due to its association with an increased risk of heart attacks and strokes. 
  • It is primarily used to relieve menopausal symptoms and in specific cases such as premature menopause.

choices.text: Take the last missed pill as soon as possible and continue the remaining packet
Take the missed pill as soon as possible and offer her emergency contraception
Take the missed pill as soon as possible and use additional contraception for 7 days
Take the missed pill as soon as possible, use emergency contraception, and discard the remaining packet

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the family planning outpatient department on Day 8 of her menstrual cycle with concerns that she missed two doses of her oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) on Days 7 and 8. She has been taking OCPs regularly for the past two years. She has no history of unprotected intercourse during the missed days. What is the most appropriate advice for her?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Take the last missed pill as soon as possible and continue the remaining packet

 

  • This patient missed two consecutive doses of her OCPs during Week 1 of her cycle. According to OCP guidelines:
  • If a woman misses one or two pills:
    • She should take the last missed pill as soon as possible (i.e., take two pills together: Day 7 and Day 8).
    • She should continue the remaining pills as scheduled.
    • No additional contraception is necessary, as long as she resumes taking the pills regularly.
  • Emergency contraception is not required unless she has had unprotected intercourse in the past 5 days, which she denies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Take the missed pill as soon as possible and offer her emergency contraception: Incorrect. Emergency contraception is not necessary for missing only two pills unless unprotected intercourse occurred during the missed days.

 

Option C. Take the missed pill as soon as possible and use additional contraception for 7 days: Incorrect. Additional contraception (e.g., condoms) is only needed if three or more pills are missed or if she had unprotected intercourse while missing the pills.

 

Option D. Take the missed pill as soon as possible, use emergency contraception, and discard the remaining packet: Incorrect. The patient should not discard the packet. She should resume the pills immediately, and emergency contraception is unnecessary unless unprotected intercourse occurred.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For women who miss one or two OCPs, they should take the missed pills immediately and continue the regular dosing schedule. Additional contraception is not needed unless three or more pills are missed, or unprotected intercourse occurred during the missed days.

choices.text: Perform amniocentesis to assess bilirubin levels
Proceed with cordocentesis and consider intrauterine transfusion if fetal PCV <30%
Administer corticosteroids and plan for early delivery
Repeat MCA Doppler in one week

questions.text: A 30-year-old G2P1 woman presents to the OPD at 28 weeks of gestation for routine follow-up. She has a history of Rh incompatibility in her previous pregnancy, which resulted in neonatal jaundice requiring phototherapy. Her current indirect Coombs test (ICT) shows a titer of 1:64, and middle cerebral artery (MCA) Doppler ultrasound reveals a peak systolic velocity (PSV) of 1.6 MoM. Fetal ultrasound shows mild ascites. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Proceed with cordocentesis and consider intrauterine transfusion if fetal PCV <30%

 

  • This patient has Rh alloimmunization with a significantly elevated MCA PSV (>1.5 MoM), suggesting moderate to severe fetal anemia. 
  • The presence of mild fetal ascites further supports the diagnosis of hydrops fetalis in its early stage. 
  • The best next step is to confirm fetal anemia via cordocentesis (percutaneous umbilical blood sampling - PUBS). 
  • If the fetal packed cell volume (PCV) is <30%, an intrauterine transfusion should be performed to prevent worsening fetal complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Perform amniocentesis to assess bilirubin levels: Previously used (Liley’s curve) but now largely replaced by MCA Doppler, which is a more reliable and non-invasive method to assess fetal anemia.

 

Option C. Administer corticosteroids and plan for early delivery: Corticosteroids may be given if preterm delivery is imminent, but in this case, the priority is to treat fetal anemia before considering delivery.

 

Option D. Repeat MCA Doppler in one week: With a markedly elevated MCA PSV (>1.5 MoM), waiting is inappropriate as it could lead to worsening anemia and fetal hydrops. Immediate cordocentesis and transfusion is needed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In Rh alloimmunization, an MCA PSV >1.5 MoM indicates moderate to severe fetal anemia. The next step is cordocentesis to assess fetal hemoglobin levels. 
  • If PCV <30%, an intrauterine transfusion is required to correct anemia and prevent complications.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman in her third trimester presents for a routine checkup. Which of the following changes is not observed in a normal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Increase in blood viscosity

 

  • During pregnancy, blood viscosity decreases due to a larger increase in plasma volume compared to red cell mass (physiological hemodilution). 
  • This reduction in viscosity helps improve uteroplacental perfusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fall in serum iron concentration: This occurs due to the increased demand for iron during pregnancy, especially in the second and third trimesters, leading to a physiological state of iron deficiency if supplementation is not provided.

 

Option B. Increase in serum iron-binding capacity: Serum iron-binding capacity increases due to elevated levels of transferrin, reflecting the body’s adaptation to the increased iron demands of pregnancy.

 

Option D. Increase in blood oxygen-carrying capacity: Despite the decrease in hemoglobin concentration due to hemodilution, the total hemoglobin mass increases by 18–20%, leading to an overall increase in the oxygen-carrying capacity of blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • During pregnancy, blood viscosity decreases due to hemodilution, while serum iron concentration falls, iron-binding capacity increases, and blood oxygen-carrying capacity rises due to increased hemoglobin mass.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding chest trauma are true? 

 

  1. ECG should be performed in all cases with associated sternal fracture
  2. Underwater seal drainage is indicated if pneumothorax is present
  3. Diaphragmatic rupture is best diagnosed by surgical exploration
  4. Urgent surgery is required in all cases of massive hemothorax
  5. Sternal fractures are markers of possible associated internal injuries
questions.solution:
Ans. A) A, B, C, E

 

A. True: ECG should be performed in all cases with associated sternal fracture: Sternal fractures can be associated with blunt cardiac injuries. ECG is the first diagnostic tool used to assess myocardial involvement.

 

B. True: Underwater seal drainage is indicated if pneumothorax is present: In cases of pneumothorax secondary to chest trauma, intercostal drainage with an underwater seal is the standard initial management.

 

C. True: Diaphragmatic rupture is best diagnosed by surgical exploration: Diaphragmatic rupture is best diagnosed by surgical exploration, as X ray or CT may miss the rupture.

 

E. True: Sternal fractures are markers of possible associated internal injuries: Sternal fractures should raise suspicion for other potentially life-threatening injuries such as myocardial rupture or thoracic aortic injury.

 

Incorrect statement:

 

D. False: Urgent surgery is required in all cases of massive hemothorax: Urgent surgery is not required in all massive hemothorax cases. Indications include blood output of 1500 cc instantly or > 250 ml/hour for 3 consecutive hours.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chest trauma evaluation begins with clinical assessment, followed by imaging such as chest X-ray. 
  • ECG is essential in suspected cardiac involvement, especially with sternal fractures. 
  • Not all cases require surgical intervention; conservative management is often sufficient depending on associated injuries.

choices.text: Submental, submandibular, deep cervical, posterior triangle
Submental, submandibular, deep cervical, posterior triangle, central

questions.text: A 60-year-old male diagnosed with squamous cell carcinoma of the lateral border of the tongue undergoes neck imaging, which shows ipsilateral level II cervical lymphadenopathy. The surgical team decides to proceed with a modified radical neck dissection. Which cervical lymph node levels are included in this procedure?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Submental, submandibular, deep cervical, posterior triangle

 

Modified Radical Neck Dissection (MRND) involves:

 

  • Removal of all lymph node groups from Level I to Level V
  • Preservation of one or more non-lymphatic structures, such as:
    • Spinal accessory nerve (SAN)
    • Internal jugular vein (IJV)
    • Sternocleidomastoid muscle (SCM)

 

Level I: Submental (Ia) and submandibular (Ib) nodes.

 

Level II: Upper jugular nodes (superior to the hyoid bone).

 

Level III: Middle jugular nodes (between the hyoid bone and the cricoid cartilage).

 

Level IV: Lower jugular nodes (inferior to the cricoid cartilage).

 

Level V: Posterior triangle nodes (including supraclavicular nodes).

 

Level VI: Anterior compartment nodes (pretracheal and paratracheal).

 

Level VII: Mediastinal nodes (not always included in neck classifications). 

 

  • Preservation of one or more non-lymphatic structures, such as:
    • Spinal accessory nerve (SAN)
    • Internal jugular vein (IJV)
    • Sternocleidomastoid muscle (SCM)

 

This procedure aims to preserve function while still providing oncologic control of nodal metastases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Modified radical neck dissection includes levels I to V cervical lymph nodes, with preservation of one or more of the accessory nerve, sternocleidomastoid muscle, or internal jugular vein, and is performed to manage cervical metastases while reducing functional morbidity.

questions.text: A 9-month-old infant in a JE-endemic area is scheduled to receive the SA 14-14-2 vaccine under the national immunization program. What is the correct dosage and route of administration for this vaccine?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 0.5 mL subcutaneous dose

 

  • The SA 14-14-2 vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine used for protection against Japanese Encephalitis (JE). 
  • Under India’s Universal Immunization Program (UIP), it is administered as a single 0.5 mL dose via the subcutaneous route, typically given at 9 months of age in endemic areas.
  • This vaccine helps build long-term immunity and is a critical tool in preventing JE outbreaks in rural and high-risk regions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The SA 14-14-2 vaccine for Japanese Encephalitis is administered as a 0.5 mL subcutaneous dose under the national immunization schedule.

choices.text: Sensitivity and specificity have improved due to lower disease burden

questions.text: Following the successful implementation of a disease control program, the prevalence of a particular infectious disease in the community has decreased by 90%. A physician continues using the same diagnostic test to identify the disease. Which of the following best describes how the test's performance is now affected?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Negative predictive value has increased

 

  • When disease prevalence decreases, the negative predictive value (NPV) of a diagnostic test increases. 
  • This means the probability that a negative test result truly rules out the disease becomes higher. Predictive values are directly influenced by disease prevalence:
  • As prevalence drops:
    → Positive Predictive Value (PPV)decreases
    → Negative Predictive Value (NPV)increases
  • The test’s sensitivity and specificity, however, are intrinsic properties of the test and remain unchanged regardless of disease prevalence.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Test specificity has increased: Incorrect. Specificity is an inherent property of the test and remains constant, regardless of disease prevalence.

 

Option B. Positive predictive value has increased: Incorrect. In fact, as prevalence decreases, PPV decreases because false positives make up a larger proportion of the positive results.

 

Option D. Sensitivity and specificity have improved due to lower disease burden: Incorrect. Sensitivity and specificity are fixed characteristics of the test and do not vary with disease prevalence.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • When disease prevalence decreases, the negative predictive value of a diagnostic test increases, making negative results more reliable.

questions.text: Under India’s Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme (IDSP), various levels of disease reporting are followed to enable early detection and response to outbreaks. At the Primary Health Centre (PHC) level, which type of diagnosis is typically made by the Medical Officer?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Probable case

 

  • In the IDSP reporting system, three levels of diagnosis are defined:
    1. Syndromic diagnosis – Based on symptoms alone, reported by health workers, ANMs, or peripheral workers.
    2. Probable diagnosis – Made by medical officers at PHC level based on clinical findings, without laboratory confirmation.
    3. Laboratory-confirmed diagnosis – Requires specific lab tests done at designated diagnostic centers.
  • Thus, PHC Medical Officers typically classify patients as probable cases, based on their clinical judgment and examination findings.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Confirmed case: Requires lab confirmation and is not determined by PHC doctors unless lab reports are available.

 

Option C. Laboratory diagnosis: Requires diagnostic testing, usually done at district or referral laboratories, not at PHC level.

 

Option D. Syndromic diagnosis: This level is used by field-level workers who report based on symptom patterns—not by medical officers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Under IDSP, PHC Medical Officers classify patients as probable cases based on clinical diagnosis without laboratory confirmation.

questions.text: A reproductive health researcher is evaluating the performance of a new contraceptive method by tracking the number of failures occurring in each individual month of use over time. Which of the following statistical tools is most appropriate for analyzing this type of month-by-month failure data?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Life table method

 

  • The life table method is the correct analytical tool to calculate the failure rate of a contraceptive for each month of use. 
  • It is designed for time-to-event (survival) analysis, where the focus is on how long individuals remain event-free—in this case, pregnancy-free—while using a contraceptive.
  • This method accounts for varying durations of exposure, loss to follow-up, and allows for interval-specific failure rates to be calculated, such as monthly or yearly risk. 
  • It provides a dynamic and detailed view of contraceptive effectiveness over time, which is more accurate than methods that simply average rates over a total period.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Couple protection rate: This measures the proportion of eligible couples effectively protected against pregnancy by any method of contraception at a given time. It is a coverage indicator, not a method to calculate failure rate per month of use.

 

Option C. Gross fertility rate: This is a demographic indicator that estimates the number of births per 1,000 women of reproductive age in a year. It is unrelated to contraceptive failure or month-specific risk.

 

Option D. Pearl Index: Though commonly used to express contraceptive failure rates, it calculates the number of failures per 100 woman-years of exposure. It does not assess failure by individual months, and it is less precise when follow-up durations vary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The life table method is used to calculate the failure rate of a contraceptive method for each individual month of use, offering interval-specific accuracy over time.

questions.text: A clinical trial is assessing time-to-event outcomes (survival) in patients receiving two different cancer therapies. The data are plotted using Kaplan-Meier survival curves for both groups. Which of the following statistical methods is most appropriate for comparing the difference in survival between the two groups, while accounting for covariates?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cox proportional hazards model

 

  • The Cox proportional hazards model is a regression technique used to analyze survival data, particularly when comparing Kaplan-Meier survival curves. It allows for:
    • Comparison of survival between groups
    • Adjustment for covariates (e.g., age, gender, comorbidities)
    • Estimation of hazard ratios to quantify relative risk over time
  • This makes it ideal for analyzing and comparing survival data in clinical research.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bland-Altman analysis: Used to compare agreement between two quantitative measurement methods, not for survival analysis.

 

Option C. Chi-square test: Used for binary outcomes (e.g., dead or alive), but does not account for time-to-event data, making it inappropriate for comparing survival curves.

 

Option D. One-way ANOVA: Used to compare means across multiple groups, assuming normally distributed continuous data, not applicable for survival/time-to-event data.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The Cox proportional hazards model is used to compare Kaplan-Meier survival curves, especially when adjusting for covariates in time-to-event analysis.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old woman presents with a racing heartbeat occurring intermittently for 6 months. She has a history of thyrotoxicosis, managed with propranolol and carbimazole.

 

Investigations:

 

  • ECG – shown below: 

 

 

Which is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Wolff-Parkinson-White Syndrome

 

  • The patient’s symptoms and ECG findings are consistent with Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) syndrome, a condition caused by the presence of an accessory conduction pathway (the Bundle of Kent).

 

Key ECG Features of WPW Syndrome:

 

  1. Short PR interval (<0.12 seconds) – Indicates premature ventricular excitation due to the accessory pathway bypassing the AV node.
  2. Delta wave (slurred upstroke of the QRS complex) – Seen in WPW due to early ventricular activation.
  3. Broad QRS complex (>0.12 seconds) – Caused by fusion of normal conduction and conduction through the accessory pathway.

 

Why WPW Syndrome?

 

  • The patient’s intermittent palpitations suggest a paroxysmal tachyarrhythmia.
  • WPW syndrome can cause AV reentrant tachycardia (AVRT) or atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response.
  • Thyrotoxicosis increases sympathetic tone, making tachyarrhythmias more likely.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atrial fibrillation: Typically shows irregularly irregular rhythm with no P waves on ECG, which is not seen here.

 

Option B. Supraventricular tachycardia (SVT): Regular narrow-complex tachycardia without the short PR interval or delta waves.

 

Option C. Torsades de pointes: Characterized by polymorphic broad QRS complexes with a twisting pattern, usually associated with a prolonged QT interval, not present here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Wolff-Parkinson-White syndrome is an accessory pathway disorder characterized by a short PR interval, delta waves, and broad QRS complexes. 
  • It can present with intermittent palpitations and is often triggered by increased sympathetic activity, such as in thyrotoxicosis.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old man presents after collapsing during a rugby match. He has since regained consciousness. On examination, he has a jerky carotid pulse and an ejection systolic murmur.

 

Investigations:

 

  • ECG Shown below: 

 

 

What is the most likely inheritance pattern?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Autosomal dominant

 

  • This presentation is highly suggestive of Hypertrophic Obstructive Cardiomyopathy (HOCM), an autosomal dominant condition characterized by:
  • Syncope or sudden cardiac arrest during exertion due to arrhythmias or obstruction of left ventricular outflow.
  • Jerky carotid pulse due to impaired cardiac output.
  • Ejection systolic murmur, which increases with maneuvers like the Valsalva maneuver.

 

ECG Findings in HOCM:

 

  • Left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH): Voltage criteria met for LVH.
  • T wave inversion in precordial leads (V1–V5): Suggestive of strain pattern due to hypertrophy.
  • Deep Q waves in inferior/lateral leads (III, aVF): Caused by hypertrophy of the interventricular septum.

 

Genetics of HOCM:

 

  • HOCM is caused by mutations in genes encoding sarcomeric proteins (e.g., MYH7 or MYBPC3).
  • The inheritance pattern is autosomal dominant, with variable penetrance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Autosomal recessive: Rarely associated with sarcomeric protein mutations. Autosomal recessive patterns are more common in metabolic cardiomyopathies, such as Pompe disease, not HOCM.

 

Option C. Mitochondrial: Mitochondrial inheritance typically causes cardiomyopathies associated with multisystem disorders (e.g., MELAS syndrome), not isolated HOCM.

 

Option D. X-linked dominant: Rare and usually associated with Fabry disease, which may cause LVH but lacks the characteristic findings of HOCM.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HOCM is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by exertional syncope, LVH, and ECG changes (T wave inversion, deep Q waves). It is a common cause of sudden cardiac death in young athletes.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy from Ranchi is brought to the paediatric rheumatology clinic with a 3-month history of intermittent high-grade fever and progressive joint pain. He reports morning stiffness lasting over an hour, primarily affecting his knees and wrists, with swelling and restricted movement. For the past week, he’s had daily fever spikes reaching 39°C, typically occurring in the evening, and transient rashes over the axilla and trunk that appear during febrile episodes and fade quickly shown below. 

 

 

On examination, he has splenomegaly and mild anemia, but no lymphadenopathy. His ANA is negative, and blood cultures are sterile.

 

What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Still’s disease 

 

  • This presentation is highly suggestive of Still’s disease (systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis, sJIA), a subtype of JIA that presents with both systemic and joint symptoms.

 

Key Features of Still’s Disease (sJIA):

 

  • Arthritis (polyarthritis pattern) → Joint pain and morning stiffness improving during the day.
  • Quotidian fever (spiking daily fevers >39°C) → Common hallmark of Still’s disease.
  • Evanescent salmon-pink rash → Typically appears with fevers, often on the trunk or axilla.
  • Splenomegaly (and possibly hepatomegaly or lymphadenopathy) → Systemic involvement.
  • Negative ANA and RF (seronegative) → A diagnostic feature of systemic JIA.

 

Yamaguchi Criteria for Adult-Onset Still’s Disease (also applicable to systemic JIA):

 

Requires ≥5 criteria, including ≥2 major criteria:

 

  • Major Criteria:
    • Fever ≥39°C for ≥1 week (Quotidian pattern)
    • Arthralgia or arthritis for ≥2 weeks
    • Salmon-pink, evanescent rash
    • Leukocytosis (≥10,000/μL) with neutrophilia
  • Minor Criteria:
    • Sore throat
    • Lymphadenopathy or splenomegaly
    • Abnormal liver function tests
    • Negative ANA and RF

 

This patient meets:

 

  • 3 major criteria: Fever, arthralgia, and rash
  • 2 minor criteria: Splenomegaly, negative ANA

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osteoarthritis: Non-inflammatory arthritis, no fever or systemic symptoms, and rare in adolescents.

 

Option B. Rheumatoid arthritis (RA): Presents with polyarthritis, but systemic features like high fever and rash are uncommon, and RA factor or anti-CCP positivity is typical in adults.

 

Option D. Systemic sclerosis: Characterized by skin thickening, Raynaud’s phenomenon, and internal organ fibrosis, which is absent here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Systemic Juvenile Idiopathic Arthritis (Still’s disease) presents with polyarthritis, quotidian fever, salmon-pink rash, and splenomegaly. Negative ANA and RF are typical. 
  • Diagnosis is based on Yamaguchi criteria, and treatment includes NSAIDs, corticosteroids, and biologics (e.g., IL-1 or IL-6 inhibitors).

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman from Indore presents with progressive abdominal discomfort, early satiety, bloating, and decreased urine output for the past month. She also reports episodes of visible blood in the urine and a dull aching pain in both flanks. Her medical history is notable for hypertension, and her younger brother is on dialysis for chronic kidney disease. On examination, her blood pressure is 154/93 mmHg, and she has mild abdominal tenderness with ballotable bilateral flank masses. What is the most appropriate investigation?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Renal Ultrasound (US)

 

  • This patient has autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD), suggested by:
  • Family history of PKD
  • Hypertension (common early finding in PKD)
  • Flank pain and hematuria (due to cyst rupture or hemorrhage)
  • Palpable kidneys (enlarged due to multiple renal cysts)

 

Why Renal Ultrasound (US)?

 

  • First-line test for diagnosing ADPKD
  • High sensitivity and specificity
  • Diagnostic criteria for ADPKD on ultrasound:
    • <30 years: ≥2 cysts (unilateral or bilateral)
    • 30–59 years: ≥2 cysts in each kidney
    • ≥60 years: ≥4 cysts in each kidney

 

Ultrasound is preferred over genetic testing, as it is cheaper, noninvasive, and widely available.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Genetic Testing:

 

  • PKD1 and PKD2 gene mutations confirm ADPKD, but genetic testing is not necessary for diagnosis in most cases.
  • Renal ultrasound is faster and cost-effective.
  • Genetic testing is usually reserved for inconclusive cases or early detection in family planning.

 

Option C. Serum Creatinine:

 

  • Serum creatinine helps assess kidney function, but it does not diagnose PKD.
  • Patients with early PKD may have normal renal function despite cystic changes.

 

Option D. Urinalysis:

 

  • May show hematuria or mild proteinuria, but it is not diagnostic for PKD.
  • Useful for ruling out concurrent infection but not the first-line investigation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Renal ultrasound is the first-line investigation for diagnosing autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). It is noninvasive, widely available, and can confirm the presence of multiple cysts. Genetic testing is usually reserved for inconclusive cases.

questions.text: A researcher is testing a new drug’s efficacy and sets the significance level at 0.05. After performing the hypothesis test, the p-value obtained is 0.02, leading the researcher to reject the null hypothesis. However, it is later revealed that the drug has no statistically significant difference with the true mean. What type of error did the researcher commit?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Type 1 error

questions.text: A female patient with a history of Diuretic abuse for the past 2 weeks presents to the ED with altered sensorium. On examination, blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. With respect to extracellular fluid volume (ECF), intracellular fluid volume (ICF), and plasma sodium, which of the following changes will this patient have?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Decreased ECF, increased ICF, and decreased plasma sodium

questions.text: Several weeks after starting a new medication for rheumatoid arthritis, a 44-year-old woman comes to the physician because of painful ulcers in her mouth. Skin examination shows soft tissue swelling over her proximal interphalangeal joints and subcutaneous nodules over her elbows. Serum studies show an alanine aminotransferase level of 220 U/L, aspartate aminotransferase level of 214 U/L, and creatinine level of 1.7 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely primary mechanism of action of the drug she is taking?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Inhibition of AICAR transformylase

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the clinic with a history of frequent falls and difficulty with balance, especially when walking. Upon examination, he displays unsteady gait and mild tremor. The fibers from the marked region in blue primarily terminate at which of the following structures?

questions.text: An infant was brought to the pediatrics department with poor sucking and difficulty in taking feed. He also had severe foul smelling greasy loose stools. DTR are seen to be sluggish. The intestinal biopsy is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy is brought to the clinic with complaints of fatigue and weakness. Abdominal examination shows splenomegaly. The image of the peripheral smear is given below. The urine urobilinogen levels in this patient will be?

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the clinic with concerns about a lump in his neck that he noticed several weeks ago. On physical examination, a firm, non-tender nodule is palpated in the anterior neck, and the patient has visible lesions on his tongue and buccal mucosa as shown below. Genetic testing is being considered to identify the underlying mutation. Which of the following genes is most likely mutated in this patient?

questions.text: A drug is to be administered orally to a patient weighing 60 kg. The target plasma concentration is 15 mg/L, the apparent volume of distribution is 0.3 L/kg, and the bioavailability of drug is 50%. Calculate the loading dose.

questions.text: A 47-year-old animal processing worker presents with a sudden onset of fever, chest discomfort, and a dry cough. He is tachycardic and a chest X-ray is shown below. What is the most likely causative organism?

questions.text: 36-year-old woman complains of pain and foreign body sensation in her eye. questions.text: A patient with aplastic anemia undergoes bone marrow transplantation. Within 2 weeks, he presents with complaints of bloody diarrhea. questions.text: A 40-year-old man, a farmer, presents with symptoms of cough, hemoptysis, and chest pain while working in an endemic area. Which of the following parasites, whose life cycle is shown below is the most likely cause of his condition?

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presented with a painless inguinoscrotal swelling. Examination revealed a hard, non-tender swelling in the left hemi-scrotum. It was possible to get above the swelling. The ultrasound scan of testes is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text: Which of the following options is incorrect about Eale's disease?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Causes gradual painful loss of vision

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is being evaluated for seizures. A CT scan was done, and the image is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Corpus callosum lipoma

questions.text: A child was brought to the clinic for evaluation of seizures. On examination, she has a port-wine stain on her face. CT scan is shown below. Which of the following is not an ocular finding commonly associated with this disease?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Optic nerve glioma

questions.text: A 48-year-old post-cholecystectomy patient presents with pain in the right upper quadrant on the third postoperative day. Evaluation reveals a collection in Morrison's pouch. A bile leak was suspected. Which of the following investigations will be most helpful in this case?
questions.solution: Ans. B) ERCP

questions.text: A previously healthy 4-year-old girl is brought to the physician for evaluation of a 3-week history of recurrent vomiting and difficulty walking. Examination shows a broad-based gait and bilateral optic disc swelling. An MRI shows an intracranial tumor. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Medulloblastoma

choices.text: One 30mg tablet taken once within 24 hours
One 30mg tablet taken twice at an interval of 12 hours
Two 30mg tablets taken twice at an interval of 12 hours
Two 30mg tablets taken once within 24 hours

questions.text: For effective protection against pregnancy after unprotected intercourse, what is the correct method of taking centchroman?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Two 30mg tablets taken twice at an interval of 12 hours

questions.text: A statistician is working with a gynecologist on a study about "Awareness regarding Pap smear." They administer a questionnaire with 50 questions to 200 women, and each correct response gets 1 point. They find that the data are positively skewed. Which of the following is most likely to be the mean, median, and mode, respectively, of the same?
questions.solution: Ans. B) 25, 23, 20

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the emergency room by his mother for a generalized tonic-clonic seizure that occurred while attending a laser light show. His mother says that he has been otherwise healthy but "he often daydreams". Over the past several months, he has reported recurrent episodes of jerky movements of his fingers and arms. These episodes usually occurred shortly after waking up in the morning. He has not lost consciousness during these episodes. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Clobazam

questions.text: A young woman complains of excessive thirst, polyuria, and nocturia following a head injury. Her urine osmolarity is found to be 290 mOsm/L, and her 24-hour urine output is 2.75 L. The patient was asked not to consume any fluids. After 4 hours, the urine osmolality was measured to be 600 mOsm/L. MRI showed a hot spot in the posterior pituitary. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Primary polydypsia

choices.text: Type A- Associated with Helicobacter pylori

questions.text: A patient presenting with the features of heart burn and indigestion is suspected to be suffering from gastritis. With respect to type A and type B gastritis, choose the correct option.
questions.solution: Ans. C) Type A- Antrum spared

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy feels embarrassed to talk with his peers because of the persistence of a high-pitched childhood voice. At times, he has noticed that on pressing the thyroid prominence, he was able to produce an adult-type voice. Which of the following thyroplasty procedure would benefit this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Type 3

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of low-grade intermittent fever, dyspnea, and chest pain that worsens on deep inspiration. Over the past 4 weeks, she has had pain in her wrists and the fingers of both hands. During this period, she has also had difficulties working on her computer due to limited range of motion in her fingers, which tends to be more severe in the morning. Physical examination shows a high-pitched scratching sound over the left sternal border. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to reveal which of the following findings?
questions.solution: Ans. A)

questions.text: What is the GCS score of a road traffic accident victim who opens his eyes to a painful stimulus, makes some incomprehensible sounds, and has the following posture?
questions.solution: Ans. C) 6

questions.text: Identify the site of stricture
questions.solution: Ans. C) Bulbous urethra

choices.text: Regular breathing continues but depth of inspiration increases

questions.text: A study was conducted on an experimental animal to demonstrate the change in breathing patterns with transections at different levels of the brainstem. Which of the following breathing pattern is most likely observed with a complete transection at midway between pons and medulla?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Irregular but rhythmic respiration

choices.text: Donor's renal artery is end-to-end anastomosed with internal iliac artery
Donor's renal vein is end-to-end anastomosed with internal iliac vein
It is a type of orthotopic organ transplantation
The maximum safe cold storage time is 18 hours

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding kidney transplantation from a live donor.
questions.solution: Ans. A) Donor's renal artery is end-to-end anastomosed with internal iliac artery

questions.text: A 22-year-old G2P1 woman at 37 weeks of gestation presents with complaints of decreased fetal movements for 2 days. She has a history of a previous term stillbirth. A Biophysical Profile (BPP) is ordered to assess fetal well-being. Which of the is not done?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Umbilical artery Doppler

questions.text: A 2-year-old child was brought with a soft, compressible swelling at the root of the nose. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Meningoencephalocele

questions.text: A 20-year-old man was stabbed in the chest during a street fight. Blood pressure is 90/58 mm Hg, pulse is 124/min, and respirations are 30/min. The patient is in severe respiratory distress. Breath sounds are present on the left and absent on the right. Heart sounds are normal. The neck veins are distended. The patient becomes obtunded during examination. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Endotracheal intubation

questions.text: A young woman, following an intense workout involving heavy weight lifting, presents with lower back pain radiating to her right hip. MRI shows the following finding. Based on the location and radiation of her pain, which of the following is the likely deficit?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Extension of great toe

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman who is a known case of neurofibromatosis type 2 presented with a headache for a few days and 2 episodes of seizures. MRI brain shows a tumor. The biopsy of the tumor specimen is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Meningioma

questions.text: Identify the fracture from the given image
questions.solution: Ans. B) Chance fracture

choices.text: Large loop excision of the transformation zone (LEEP)

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the gynecology clinic for follow-up after an abnormal Pap smear. Her cervical cytology reveals high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion (HSIL), and colposcopy confirms cervical intraepithelial neoplasia grade 2 (CIN 2). What is the next step?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Large loop excision of the transformation zone (LEEP)

questions.text: The contraction of which muscle does the given instrument assess to monitor neuromuscular activity?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Adductor pollicis

questions.text: Which of the following drugs cannot be used to treat gastroparesis?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Loperamide

questions.text: A middle-aged man is found to have elevated levels of liver transaminases. His liver biopsy image with PAS staining is given below. The gene responsible for this condition is present on which chromosome?
questions.solution: Ans. C) 14

choices.text: Anterior deviation of the infundibular septum
Pulmonary venous connection to the SVC
Ostium secundum defect in the fossa ovalis

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary defect responsible for this condition?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Downward displacement of tricuspid valve

choices.text: Bite of an infected Aedes mosquito

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 24 weeks of gestation developed sudden-onset fever, rash, conjunctivitis, muscle and joint pain, malaise, and headache. On further evaluation, she tested positive for the Zika virus. Which of the following is not a mode of transmission of this virus?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Droplet transmission

questions.text: 35-year-old man presents to the outpatient department with complaints of fever with chills, headache, confusion, and vomiting. On cerebrospinal fluid microscopy, gram-positive rods with tumbling motility at 25°C are observed. Which is the most likely mode of transmission of this pathogen?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Contaminated food

choices.text: > 12% increase in FEV1/FVC ratio and 200 mL increase in FEV1
> 50% increase in FEV1/FVC ratio and 500 mL increase in FEV1
> 20% increase in FEV1/FVC ratio and 410 mL increase in FEV1
> 6% increase in FEV1/FVC ratio and 100 mL increase in FEV1

questions.text: Which of the following values represents the minimum change required to demonstrate the reversibility of obstruction after administration of bronchodilators in this condition?
questions.solution: Ans. A) > 12% increase in FEV1/FVC ratio and 200 mL increase in FEV1

questions.text: Which of the following regions are not commonly measured for skinfold thickness?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Mid-thigh

questions.text: An ultrasound scan of a 35-year-old woman revealed a unilocular cyst of 5 cm in her ovary. She is asymptomatic. She does not have a family history of breast, ovarian, or colon cancer. She has not received treatment for infertility in the past. CA-125 levels are <35 U/mL. What is the next best step in her treatment plan?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Follow-up after 1-2 cycles of OCPs

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl comes in with primary amenorrhea and indications of virilization. She displays underdeveloped breasts and pubic hair consistent with prepubertal stages, rated at Tanner stage 2. She has a closed-off vaginal canal and noticeable enlargement of the clitoris. Despite her female sex, her testosterone levels are within the male range. Her genetic makeup is 46XY. What is the likely medical diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution: Ans. A) 5 alpha reductase deficiency

choices.text: Elevated levels of very long chain fatty acids

questions.text: A 2-months-old infant is found to be hypotonic. On examination, there is a large anterior fontanelle and hepatomegaly. Further investigations confirmed a diagnosis of the cerebro-hepato-renal syndrome. Which of the following is not a biochemical finding in this case?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Elevated plasmalogen content

questions.text: A young man with a history of a respiratory tract infection 4 weeks ago, is unable to stand or walk for the past 2 weeks. His weakness began in the toes and ankles and progressed to involve his knee and hip joints. His upper limbs are not affected and cranial nerves are intact. On examination, there is an absent knee jerk. Which of the following would you consider as the initial therapy?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Intravenous immune globulin

questions.text: A middle-aged hypertensive man presents with acute onset pain and swelling on his toe over the left foot. X-ray is shown below. Which of the following antihypertensive drugs can be safely administered to this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Losartan

questions.text: A 73-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after the sudden onset of right-sided body weakness. His wife reports that he does not seem to understand simple questions. He has type 2 diabetes mellitus and has smoked 1 pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. The patient speaks fluently, but he answers questions with nonsensical phrases but can repeat single words. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Transcortical sensory aphasia

questions.text: 3-week-old neonate presents to the outpatient for the first time. He was born by vaginal delivery at home and has not received any vaccines. Which of the following vaccines would be indicated at this visit, as per the National Immunization Schedule?
questions.solution: Ans. A) BCG vaccine

choices.text: It produces peritrichous flagella on solid medium
It gives a positive string test

questions.text: An outbreak of food poisoning in a coastal city is determined to be due to contaminated seafood. The causative bacteria formed the following colonies on TCBS agar and showed hemolysis on Wagatsuma agar. Which of the following statements regarding the organism implicated here is false?
questions.solution: Ans. A) It is non-capsulated

questions.text:
A 40-year-old woman presents with a 6-month history of fatigue, dry eyes, and dry mouth. She also reports intermittent muscle weakness and occasional episodes of numbness in her hands. Laboratory tests reveal:

 

  • Serum potassium: 2.8 mEq/L 
  • Serum bicarbonate: 16 mEq/L 
  • Serum anion gap: 8 mEq/L 
  • Urine pH: 7.0

 

Further evaluation reveals anti-SSA and anti-SSB antibodies. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for her hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B) Distal renal tubular acidosis (dRTA)

questions.text: A 5-year-old child is brought to the pediatric neurology clinic with a history of recurrent seizures since early childhood. The seizures are characterized by abrupt loss of consciousness followed by periods of confusion. The child's developmental milestones are significantly delayed, and recent imaging studies reveal atrophy of the left cerebral hemisphere. The neurologist aims to determine the most likely epileptic syndrome associated with these clinical and radiological findings. Which epileptic syndrome is most likely associated with left hemispheric atrophy in this child?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Rasmussen encephalitis

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department for difficulty breathing and a productive cough. He has a past medical history of recurrent episodes of sinusitis and otitis media. The respiratory infections typically have a protracted course but respond to high-dose antibiotic therapy. Pulmonary auscultation shows crackles and wheezing. CXR is shown below. Which of the following is most likely to be dysfunctional in this patient?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Dynein arms

questions.text: A patient with fever, cough, and recent hotel stay has negative sputum cultures on standard media. The lab recommends a specialized medium as shown below. Which medium is used?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Buffered charcoal yeast extract (BCYE) agar

choices.text: Apical hyperkinesis with free wall akinesia
Severe mitral regurgitation with papillary muscle dysfunction

questions.text: A 63-year woman old presents to the AIIMS emergency chest pain after an RTA. Which resulted in crushed left lower limb. ECG shows 1-2 mm ST elevations in leads V2-V4 & troponin are elevated. The patient undergoes CAG which was normal. Which of the following is likely?
questions.solution: Ans. D) Akinetic LV apex with ballooning

questions.text:
Which of the following is included in high-quality CPR?

 

  1. Compression depth of at least 5 cm 
  2. Rotate chest compressor every 3 mins 
  3. Avoid excessive ventilation 
  4. Compression - ventilation ratio of 30:2
  5. Allow complete recoil 
  6. ET co2 <10mm
  7. Intra-arterial DBP >20mm Hg
  8. Breaths 20-30/min
questions.solution: Ans. D) 1, 3, 4, 5, 7

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with a 6 x 4 cm right breast lump in the upper medial quadrant. The lump is fixed to the pectoralis major. Examination reveals no axillary nodes but an enlarged left-sided supraclavicular node. Her TNM stage is:
questions.solution: Ans. C) T3N0M1

choices.text: Gastric and esophageal balloon tamponade (Sengstaken-Blakemore tube)

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient with hepatitis C with a previous history of variceal bleeding is admitted to the hospital with hematemesis. His blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg, physical examination reveals splenomegaly and ascites, and initial hematocrit is 25%. Which of the following is the next best step in management of the patient?
questions.solution: Ans. A) Administration of intravenous octreotide

questions.text: A child is diagnosed with X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets. Which of the following is true about this condition?
questions.solution: Ans. C) Normal levels of serum calcium

questions.text: A 31-year-old woman presented with headache and blurred vision. She is a known case of hypertension. Renal arteriography is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. A) FMD
